ygData.subject: URIs are RESTful
ygData.msgSnippet: ... If it s a URI, then there s nothing at all RESTless about it.  That URI is perfectly fine, even if what you GET from it differs depending upon who invoked

On Tue, Jul 01, 2003 at 10:02:16PM +0100, Vincent D Murphy wrote:
> On Tuesday, Jul 1, 2003, at 19:56 Europe/Dublin, Tyler Close wrote:
> > I am arguing against URIs like
> > <http://www.acmebank.com/accounts/current/12/>, where this URI
> > refers the 12th most recent payment made by a particular user.
> 
> ah.  thanks for that clarification.
> 
> i think your point (that such URIs are RESTless) can be more
> clearly made by stating that the only way that the 'current'
> account alluded to in your URI can be dereferenced is by having
> access to some server-side state, or a session.
> 
> this of course is RESTless all by itself because the server has
> to maintain that state using a gross hack (cf. cookies).

If it's a URI, then there's nothing at all RESTless about it.  That
URI is perfectly fine, even if what you GET from it differs depending
upon who invoked GET, the time of day, etc..  To say otherwise is
to prevent me from identifying a whole class of useful resources,
such as "The person to my right", "The colour of the next traffic
light up ahead", etc..

Mark.
